Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Fundamental Methods for Design, Control, and Motion Planning of Soft Robots

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The next frontier for robotics is bringing robots into environments such as homes, flexible manufacturing, and disaster sites, where the standard robot design, consisting of rigid links actuated by electric motors, limits their usefulness and creates safety concerns. Unlike rigid robots, soft robots have the potential to be highly accessible, versatile, and inherently safe around humans. However, there is currently a lack of engineering principles for designing soft robots that perform practical tasks. It is also unclear how to enable these robots to move reliably and efficiently in cluttered environments, like a disaster site. This work explores new methods for designing, controlling, and planning motion for soft robot arms.

The technical objective is to explore, formalize, and validate the fundamental algorithmic and engineering principles necessary to build soft robot arms and allow them to perform useful tasks. To that end, the project investigates (1) A modular soft arm design where each module can offer a combination of 3D bending, extension, and change in stiffness, (2) Modeling and control methods to achieve reliable position, force, and impedance control, and (3) Motion planning algorithms which plan in the belief space of the robot and exploit contact with the environment to overcome uncertainty in the motion model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project developed the basic science and experimental validation of pressure-operated soft robots made of self-contained modules with integrated sensing, actuation, valving, motion control, and communication capabilities, and paved the way towards safe robots that can be used in the real world, in close proximity to humans. The next frontier for robotics is bringing robots into environments such as homes, flexible manufacturing, and disaster sites, where the standard robot design, consisting of rigid links actuated by electric motors, limits their usefulness and creates safety concerns. If we build robots from soft materials, we can circumvent these concerns and limitations, but the resulting soft robots lack formal approaches and methods in design, modeling, motion control, and motion planning that were developed over decades of research for traditional robots made of rigid materials. This project addressed these challenges for a class of soft robots that utilize modular operation, which enables ease of functional scalability and maintenance.

As a result of this research, we developed mathematical models, design methodologies, and soft modular robot prototypes that offer 2-D and 3-D motion and manipulation capabilities. We developed and tested a number of motion control algorithms and reported on the limits on precision and response time of pressure-actuated soft robots to follow desired motion trajectories. We developed two new control approaches that 1) reduced the response time of the inherently slow pneumatic soft actuators, and 2) reduced the inherent nonlinearities of and variations between different soft-robotic modules. Finally, we developed new approaches to the motion planning problem of soft robots, specifically on long and slender soft robotic systems that operate similarly to a snake in locomotion and octopus arm in manipulation tasks. Based on our results, we now understand significant features of such soft robotic systems to be utilized in a repeatable and reliable manner. The snake-like platforms developed as part of this research are much lighter and exhibit fewer discrete actuation modules than a traditional rigid snake, and thus require much lower energy, while offering similar applications in search-and-rescue, inspection, and other tasks in clutter.

The project also partially supported our work in a unique new kind of sensor that was originally developed to measure the bending deformation of a soft robotic module for feedback control and described in detail on the Soft Robotics Toolkit. We recently extended this sensor to measure forces in 3-D based on a machine learning algorithm to remove nonlinearities during calibration. This new sensor is based on detecting the magnetic field variations near a miniature magnet embedded in discrete locations in silicone rubber (or any other deformable substrate). The result is an accurate, lightweight, and fast force or deformation sensor that can be embedded in a broad range of robots, devices, or materials.

Overall, 5 Ph.D. students were trained partially through this research. We gave seminars on Soft Robotics at six colleges and universities and presented papers in international conferences in robotics and other relevant fields, including an invited talk at the Materials Research Society meeting to attract new researchers into this field. We performed robot demonstrations as part of large outreach activities at WPI: TouchTomorrow, Frontiers, and National Engineers Week. We won first place in 2017 ICRA Soft Robot Speed Challenge using a soft robotic snake prototype and algorithms that resulted from this research.

Looking ahead, our work on soft robotic continuum modules, the snake-like locomotion platforms, and manipulators, as well as compliant manipulation could be used to develop more capable soft and compliant robots for use in fields such as disaster recovery, industrial manipulation, and caring for the elderly/disabled. Soft robotic continuum arms, their architecture, and associated algorithms may be useful for adjacent disciplines, where contact with the environment or humans would be inevitable, such as in surgical tools, rehabilitation, and teleoperation interfaces.
